What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)

What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)

Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
Comments_List: I learned how to analyze readings for point, style, and voice, and how to apply techniques from the readings to my own creative nonfiction essays.
Clarity of writing, essay structure and organization, logic, discussion--so many things
We learned a lot of specific writing techniques.

I learned about various skills and tools utilized by major essayists and writers, but also ways to improve the unfavorable writerly habits I end up falling into - the class really introduces you to a variety of great writers and gives you the opportunity to improve your own writing and discover your own voice.
I learned about different writing techniques and became more confident as a writer.
I learned how to structure my essays more effectively and how to phrase my sentences less awkwardly.
Increased ability to write creative nonfiction essays.
a better understanding of the tools of writing nonfiction and a greater confidence in my writing skills
Reading pieces for craft
I learned a lot about different writing techniques and strategies.
A strength of the course was that Pam gave excellent feedback on the drafts of the essays that really helped my writing to improve. Also, the readings were fun and interesting.
Fantastic course. One of the best I've taken at Yale. Few to no weaknesses. Only strengths--teacher, format, curriculum, papers.

The readings for this class were great but I thought discussion could have been better. It sometimes felt like  a high school class because we were expected to give very specific answers to discussion questions.

The strengths are the opportunities to write in itself - we really got a chance to showcase our writing and workshop them to get the most out of each assignment and each students voice; however, with the assigned readings and discussion in class, I feel as though discussion became increasingly redundant and a bit unproductive, albeit interesting nonetheless. I think by letting discussion roam more freely among students, each seminar meeting could be more interesting and productive, especially later in the semester.
I like the writing workshops and being able to submit drafts of my essays.
My strengths lie in my syntax and precision of word choice.

Strengths: good in-class teaching.
Weaknesses: comments often unhelpful or inconsistent.

the essays on the syllabus were so great and the way we discussed them in class was super effective and interesting. the format of turning in a draft then getting to revise it the next week was really great to help get specific advice on how to improve my writing
Too many readings at times; I feel as though the class could benefit from narrowing down a survey of readings per genre to a few enlightening pieces.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student because the feedback received on the drafts helped me to improve my writing skills and become more confident in my voice and style.
Yes--ABSOLUTELY. No matter what major a student is, the skills they will develop in this course will help them. Fantastic way to get a WR credit.

I really liked the reading and assignments and liked class a little but less but still would probably recommend it because the assignments were very interesting and the peer editing process is cool/ a good experience.

I would recommend this course to anyone looking to improve their overall writing ability. The course isnt necessarily about perfecting your writing or writing extremely experimental creative works, rather modeling your essays off the essays we read and mastering a more objective craft of good writing.
Yes, the readings are wonderful and have helped me improve as a writer.

Yes! This course definitely explores non-fiction writing in a nuanced yet interesting way. You learn a lot about the different techniques employed by authors and about ways you can incorporate the ones you like into your own writing. The feedback on essays are very detailed and helpful in providing directionality for improvement. English 120 was honestly one of my favorite courses this year. Truly, it was an amazing, eye-opening class. Don't believe me? Take it and see!
Yes--it was quite enjoyable, and did develop my writing.

yes!!! i think it really improved my writing skills and increased my confidence in my abilities as a writer. plus the essays we read for the class were soooo good! overall a great and fun class -- i think everyone should take english 120 before graduating!!!
Yes. It was a good class, but I definitely think it was hyped up more than necessary. Don't expect a life-changing class or anythin
Definitely recommend this class if you're interested in journalism or magazine writing. It's a good way to write about non-fiction without it being boring like a textbook or history books.
